doc.repnme: Bankruptcy's role in enterprise restructuring : a hammer to turn a screw?
doc.abstracts: State-owned enterprise restructuring has been slow in the transforming economies of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, which some have blamed on the absence or inadequacy of bankruptcy laws and procedures. And when modeling bankruptcy laws on the best laws in Europe and the United States fails to accelerate enterprise restructuring, they call for more judges and training or for mandatory out-of-court settlements. These prescriptions may be based on faulty diagnosis. In fact, bankruptcy laws are necessary only if a firm has 1) going concern value and 2) multiple claimants within the relevant class creating a free-rider problem. Three questions determine whether a bankruptcy system needs fixing: 1) Are actual or potential value-adding firms getting the funds they need for sound investments? 2) Are confirmed value-subtracting firms being liquidated? 3) Are the costs of delays in financially reorganizing sound but overly indebted firms fairly low? The trick in an effective bankruptcy system is to have those facing the greatest risk of being "out of money" keep a finger on the bankruptcy trigger. These parties should know the firm's business, be adept at negotiations, and not be plagued by the free-rider problem. Such an ideal combination is rare, but laws often reorder the pecking order of claims to ensure that it is possible.
